title: Saskatoon author Arthur Slade awarded $10K lifetime achievement prize | CBC Books
text:
Arthur Slade, author of 25 YA, middle-grade and graphic novels, has been awarded the Cheryl & Henry Kloppenburg Award for Literary Excellence, a $10,000 lifetime achievement prize given annually to a Saskatchewan writer.

The Saskatoon writer's books include Dust, winner of the 2001 Governor General's Literary Award for young people's literature — text and The Hunchback Assignments, which received the 2010 TD Canadian Children's Literature Award.

"Critically acclaimed and lauded in multiple venues around the world, Arthur Slade's writing is doing the very important work of inspiring future writerly generations by engaging young readers of today," said the jury in a press release.

"With cutting-edge graphic novels and gripping fantastical fiction, not to mention a robust online presence, Slade is extending the expectations of literary genres and placing Saskatchewan on a growing international stage of young adult literature."

Slade's latest books are from the Amber Fang series, which follows a vampire-librarian who only drinks the blood of killers.

Slade is the first YA and middle-grade writer to be chosen for this honour.

Previous winners include Yann Martel, Guy Vanderhaeghe and Lorna Crozier.
description: The longtime writer of YA fiction was given the Cheryl and Henry Kloppenburg Award for Literary Excellence for his "cutting-edge graphic novels and gripping fantastical fiction."
